facts.text: Appellant (plaintiff) and respondent (defendant) married at Patan on April 20, 1942, according to Hindu rites of the Jain Community. Families from Patan, Gujarat. Lived in Bombay two-room flat with appellant's parents and sisters.
Son Kirit born on September 10, 1945.
Mahendra, family friend, began living in Bombay flat in 1946 after army discharge.
Appellant left for England on business on January 8, 1947.

During appellant's absence, respondent became intimate with Mahendra and wrote amorous letter (Ex. E) to him in April 1947 from Patan while staying with mother-in-law. Letter admitted by respondent's counsel.
Appellant returned to Bombay on May 20, 1947. On first night, his bed made in hall by father; slept apart from wife.
On May 21, 1947 morning, appellant's father handed him Ex. E. Appellant recognized wife's handwriting, got photocopies made.
Appellant confronted wife on May 21 evening; she denied writing, then on May 23 showed photocopy, she admitted writing, said Mahendra better man, loved him.
On morning of May 24, 1947, wife said packed luggage to go to Jalgaon for cousin's marriage; appellant offered car and Rs.100, refused. Left afternoon train with all belongings.
Appellant's mother left for Patan with son some days before May 24.
Wife never returned to Bombay or wrote from Jalgaon.
Solicitor's letter (Ex. A) dated July 15, 1947 to wife at Jalgaon, charging intimacy with Mahendra, demanding child back, stating entitled to divorce, does not desire to keep her.
No reply to Ex. A; wife advised by father not to reply.

November 1947, appellant's mother informed him wife coming to Bombay soon. Appellant sent telegram (Ex. B) to father-in-law: 'Must not send Prabha. Letter posted. Wishing happy new year.' Dated Nov 13, 1947.
Carbon copy of letter (Ex. C) dated Nov 13, 1947 to father-in-law, expressing surprise at return, demanding repentance letter from wife before fetching her.
Appellant's father letter (Ex. D) Nov 15, 1947 to respondent's father, insisting consent of appellant before sending wife.
No reply to telegram, letters. Respondent denied receiving Ex. C.
May 1948, appellant met wife at Patan, asked her to return if repents for Mahendra relations; she said decided not to in Nov 1947 due to pressure.
Later 1948, appellant visited Patan as wife had typhoid; she showed no desire to return.
April-May 1949, third meeting at Jalgaon; wife refused return even for child.
Respondent's uncle Bhogilal and cousin Babubhai (Babulal) visited appellant in Bombay post Ex. A, pleaded to take her back; refused.
Respondent's father visited appellant's father post Ex. A.
Respondent and son lived with appellant's family at Patan for over 4 months off and on.
Aug-Sept 1948, son sent alone to Bombay at mother-in-law suggestion; stayed 20 days, father brought back as boy unwilling without mother.
Suit filed July 4, 1951 for dissolution on ground of desertion since May 24, 1947 for over 4 years, custody of child.
Written statement Feb 4, 1952: denied intimacy, said husband made life unbearable, compelled to leave, always willing to return, husband refused.
Single issue: Whether defendant deserted plaintiff for continuous period of over four years prior to suit.
Trial by Tendolkar J., Bombay HC Original Side: plaintiff examined self; defendant, father Popatlal, cousin Bhogilal. Issue affirmed, decree for dissolution March 7, 1952, no costs.
Appeal No. 66 of 1952, Division Bench Chagla CJ and Bhagwati J: allowed appeal, set aside decree, dismissed suit with costs Aug 22, 1952.
Leave to appeal to SC refused by another Division Bench; special leave granted by SC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the defendant deserted the plaintiff for a continuous period of over four years prior to the filing of the suit under section 3(1)(d) of the Bombay Hindu Divorce Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defendant deserted since May 24, 1947 without reasonable cause and against his will, with animus deserendi; letter Ex. E shows intimacy with Mahendra; refused to return despite opportunities; solicitor letter was shock treatment.
Defendant admitted letter, no innocent explanation; bed incident shows intent to separate; never wrote to return.

respondent_arguments.text: Plaintiff made life unbearable post-return from England; compelled to leave May 24, 1947 against wishes; always ready and willing to return; plaintiff refused via solicitor letter, telegram, etc.; relatives pleaded, he refused.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: No desertion; constructive desertion by plaintiff

respondent_arguments.text: Lived with husband's family at Patan off and on; sent son to induce return.

court_reasoning.text: Letter Ex. E suspicious, shows amorous correspondence unworthy of wife, consciousness of guilt, but not proof of sexual intercourse; justified husband's suspicion and demand for repentance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wife's explanation disingenuous; husband more sinned against.

court_reasoning.text: Departure May 24 consistent with shame after discovery, not necessarily permanent desertion; no animus deserendi proved at outset.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden on petitioner to prove desertion beyond reasonable doubt throughout 4 years.

court_reasoning.text: Solicitor letter Ex. A (July 15, 1947) shows husband not willing to receive back, determined not to keep her; no allegation of desertion therein.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deserted spouse must affirm marriage and be willing to resume.

court_reasoning.text: Telegram Ex. B and Ex. D peremptory, countermand return; Ex. C dubious.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Husband not ready to receive without repentance.

court_reasoning.text: Wife's relatives' evidence corroborates her willingness: visits to plead, stays at Patan with in-laws, sending son; husband's evidence uncorroborated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accept respondent's case; no proof of continuous desertion.

court_reasoning.text: Desertion requires factum of separation + animus deserendi; must persist 4 years; presumption rebutted by evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff fails to prove beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.text: No desertion by defendant proved; essential ingredients not established; plaintiff failed burden of proof.

precedents_cited.relevance: Corroboration required as precaution in divorce cases.
Desertion not single act; purpose from conduct.
Party intending to end cohabitation commits desertion.
Factum + animus deserendi; who leaves not decisive if constructive desertion.
Desertion must persist throughout period; petitioner's attitude matters.
Guilty party not always who leaves.
Look to conduct and real intention.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Hindu Divorce Act, XXII of 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Ground of divorce for desertion for continuous 4 years without reasonable cause and without consent; definition of desertion.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; agreed with High Court Appellate Bench that no desertion proved; suit for dissolution dismissed.
outcome.costs: Not specified in SC judgment; High Court had costs to respondent.

key_quotes.text: "Desertion is the separation of one spouse from the other, with an intention on the part of the deserting spouse of bringing cohabitation permanently to an end without reasonable cause and without the consent of the other spouse but the physical act of departure by one spouse does not necessarily make that spouse the deserting party."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Definition from Rayden on Divorce summarizing desertion elements.

key_quotes.text: "In its essence desertion means the intentional permanent forsaking and abandonment of one spouse by the other without that others consent, and without reasonable cause. It is a total repudiation of the obligations of marriage."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Halsbury; core essence of desertion.

key_quotes.text: The matters on which we were to remain anxious and you particularly were anxious, well we need not be. I very much repented later on in my mind. But after all love is such an affair. Love begets love.
key_quotes.speaker: respondent
key_quotes.significance: Key excerpt from Ex. E love letter triggering suspicions.

key_quotes.text: "Our client has become entitled to obtain a divorce and our client does not desire to keep you any longer under his care and protection."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner
key_quotes.significance: Solicitor letter Ex. A showing husband's unwillingness to resume cohabitation.
